title: Facebook’s social Zoom competitor Messenger Rooms goes live globally – TechCrunch
summary:
Zoom was never meant to be a social network, but the enterprise video chat app has become essential software for those looking to stay in touch with friends and family during the pandemic.
Today, Facebook looks to steal back the service’s social video chat growth as it globally launches Messenger Rooms, its new group video chat service, supporting video calls with up to 50 participants with no time limits on call length.
For now users can kick off a call from Messenger or the Facebook app and send out invites to users, even ones that don’t have a Facebook account.
During the latest earnings call, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said time on group video chats had increased 1,000% in recent weeks.
With Messenger Rooms, Facebook is looking to create a scalable, free alternative and steal back some of the conversation from platforms like Zoom and TikTok, which have been awfully buzzy during recent months.
text:
Zoom was never meant to be a social network, but the enterprise video chat app has become essential software for those looking to stay in touch with friends and family during the pandemic.

Today, Facebook looks to steal back the service’s social video chat growth as it globally launches Messenger Rooms, its new group video chat service, supporting video calls with up to 50 participants with no time limits on call length. The feature capitalizes on video chat’s massive spike in usage across services and hooks it up to the growth tactics Facebook used to push Facebook and Instagram Live into everyone’s feeds.

Messenger Rooms is a drop-in video chat, so when a friend using the feature creates a room, Facebook will alert users via a new section in the news feed or push a notification to certain friends. As Facebook detailed when it announced the feature, soon users will also be able to join and initiate calls from inside Instagram DMs, WhatsApp and on Portal, making this a company-wide social effort for the company.

For now users can kick off a call from Messenger or the Facebook app and send out invites to users, even ones that don’t have a Facebook account.

During the latest earnings call, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said time on group video chats had increased 1,000% in recent weeks. Given the feature’s social grounding and lack of screen sharing, the app isn’t likely to scale heavily into enterprise use cases and infringe on Zoom’s core business. With Messenger Rooms, Facebook is looking to create a scalable, free alternative and steal back some of the conversation from platforms like Zoom and TikTok, which have been awfully buzzy during recent months.

<div id="root">

		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">Facebook’s social Zoom competitor Messenger Rooms goes live globally</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/lucas-matney/">
			Lucas Matney		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
							<a href="https://twitter.com/lucasmtny">@lucasmtny</a>
				<span class="text--green"> / </span>
						6 days		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Facebook-Messenger-Rooms.jpg?w=730" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary"><a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/organization/zoom-video-communications" target="_blank" data-type="organization" data-entity="zoom-video-communications">Zoom <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> was never meant to be a social network, but the enterprise video chat app has become essential software for those looking to stay in touch with friends and family during the pandemic.</p>
<p>Today, <a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/organization/facebook" target="_blank" data-type="organization" data-entity="facebook">Facebook <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> looks to steal back the service’s social video chat growth as it globally launches Messenger Rooms, its new group video chat service, supporting video calls with up to 50 participants with no time limits on call length. The feature capitalizes on video chat’s massive spike in usage across services and hooks it up to the growth tactics Facebook used to push <a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/organization/facebook" target="_blank" data-type="organization" data-entity="facebook">Facebook <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> and Instagram Live into everyone’s feeds.</p>
<p><a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/organization/messenger" target="_blank" data-type="organization" data-entity="messenger">Messenger <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> Rooms is a drop-in video chat, so when a friend using the feature creates a room, Facebook will alert users via a new section in the news feed or push a notification to certain friends. As Facebook detailed when it announced the feature, soon users will also be able to join and initiate calls from inside <a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/organization/instagram" target="_blank" data-type="organization" data-entity="instagram">Instagram <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> DMs, WhatsApp and on Portal, making this a company-wide social effort for the company.</p><div class="piano-inline-promo"></div>
<p>For now users can kick off a call from Messenger or the Facebook app and send out invites to users, even ones that don’t have a Facebook account.</p>
<p>During the latest earnings call, Facebook CEO <a class="crunchbase-link" href="https://crunchbase.com/person/mark-zuckerberg" target="_blank" data-type="person" data-entity="mark-zuckerberg">Mark Zuckerberg <span class="crunchbase-tooltip-indicator"></span></a> said time on group video chats had increased 1,000% in recent weeks. Given the feature’s social grounding and lack of screen sharing, the app isn’t likely to scale heavily into enterprise use cases and infringe on Zoom’s core business. With Messenger Rooms, Facebook is looking to create a scalable, free alternative and steal back some of the conversation from platforms like Zoom and TikTok, which have been awfully buzzy during recent months.</p>

Two Democratic senators \u2014 including former presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders \u2014 were nowhere to be seen and neither returned a request for comment.<\/p>\n<p>It was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wyden.senate.gov\/news\/press-releases\/wyden-opposes-warrantless-government-surveillance-of-americans-internet-browsing-history\">one of several amendments<\/a> offered up in the effort to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/13\/senate-warrant-americans-web-browsing-data\/\">reform and reauthorize<\/a> the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, the basis of U.S. spying laws. The law, signed in 1978, put restrictions on who intelligence agencies could target with their vast listening and collection stations. But <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/26\/nsa-improper-phone-records-collection\/\">after the Edward Snowden revelations in 2013<\/a>, lawmakers champed at the bit to change the system to better protect Americans, who are largely protected from the spies within its borders.<\/p>\n<p>One <a href=\"https:\/\/www.lee.senate.gov\/public\/index.cfm\/press-releases?ContentRecord_id=56990D34-B897-4138-8F03-9D85464C7130\">privacy-focused amendment<\/a>, brought by Sens. Mike Lee and Patrick Leahy, passed \u2014 permits for more independent oversight to the secretive and typically one-sided Washington, D.C. court that authorizes government surveillance programs, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. That amendment all but guarantees the bill will bounce back to the House for further scrutiny.<\/p>\n<p>Here’s more from the week.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h2 id=\"THE BIG PICTURE\">THE BIG PICTURE<\/h2>\n<h2 id=\"Three years after WannaCry, U.S. still on North Korea's tail\">Three years after WannaCry, U.S. still on North Korea’s tail<\/h2>\n<p>A <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wired.com\/story\/confessions-marcus-hutchins-hacker-who-saved-the-internet\/\">feature-length profile<\/a> in Wired magazine looks at the life of Marcus Hutchins, one of the heroes who helped stop <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/07\/08\/the-wannacry-sinkhole\/\">the world’s biggest cyberattack<\/a> three years to the day.<\/p>\n<p>The profile \u2014 a <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/a_greenberg\/status\/1260173846994472961\">14,000-word cover story<\/a> \u2014 examines his part in halting the spread of the global WannaCry ransomware attack and how his early days led him into a criminal world that prompted him to plead guilty to felony hacking charges. Thanks in part to his efforts in saving the internet, he was sentenced to time served and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/07\/26\/marcus-hutchins-sentenced-kronos\/\">walked free<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>One vote. america","slug":"north-america","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/7723"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=7723"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=7723"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=7723"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=7723"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":192933,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ransomware\/","name":"ransomware","slug":"ransomware","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/192933"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=192933"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":7054,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/senate\/","name":"senate","slug":"senate","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/7054"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=7054"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1990624,"date":"2020-05-19T04:36:20","date_gmt":"2020-05-19T11:36:20","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1990624"},"modified":"2020-05-19T06:59:13","modified_gmt":"2020-05-19T13:59:13","slug":"walmart-says-it-will-discontinue-jet-com-which-it-acquired-for-3b-in-2016","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/19\/walmart-says-it-will-discontinue-jet-com-which-it-acquired-for-3b-in-2016\/","title":{"rendered":"Walmart says it will discontinue Jet, which it acquired for $3B in 2016"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">So much for Walmart’s big and expensive effort to take on Amazon with a digitally-native brand. Amid the coronavirus crisis and its impact on the retail industry, today the retail giant quietly\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/stock.walmart.com\/investors\/financial-information\/sec-filings\/sec-filings-details\/default.aspx?FilingId=14159959\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">announced in its quarterly report<\/a> that it would be discontinuing Jet.com, the online-only marketplace that it <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/08\/08\/confirmed-walmart-buys-jet-com-for-3b-in-cash\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">acquired when it was just over one year old for $3 billion<\/a>\u00a0(plus $300 million in earn-outs over time), as it struggles to bring its e-commerce operations into that black after <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/walmarts-secret-weapon-to-fight-off-amazon-the-supercenter-11576904460\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">reportedly<\/a>\u00a0seeing a loss of $2 billion in the division in 2019 and shifting how to deliver its e-commerce strategy: by betting on giant stores, rather than online warehouses, as the hubs of its online delivery model.<\/p>\n<p>Jet.com’s fate was disclosed as part of a Walmart’s Q1 earnings report, in which the company said it saw growth of less than 10% in its core US market, and said that it would be withdrawing guidance for fiscal 2021.<\/p>\n<p>The company tried to put a positive spin on the news despite those numbers highlighting how it helped its digital transformation. “<span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Due to continued strength of the Walmart.com brand, the company will discontinue Jet.com,” the company said in a short statement. “The acquisition of Jet.com nearly four years ago was critical to accelerating our omni strategy.” <\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Yet t<\/span>he news of Jet.com’s discontinuation is in equal parts a surprise if probably expected by those who have been watching its progress. Surprise, because the continued impact of COVID-19 has led to a surge of people shopping online — Walmart itself notes that e-commerce sales were up 74% in the quarter, including store pickup and delivery, ship to home, ship from store and marketplace channels — and so it would seem that Walmart might have wanted to double down on its own online efforts.<\/p>\n<p>Expected, because in reality Jet.com hasn’t shaped up to be the jewel in the crown that Walmart had hoped it would become, going through a number of restructuring attempts over the years as e-commerce overall continued to bleed red.<\/p>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 4\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<p>The earnings report noted that revenue for the company this quarter was $134.6 billion, an increase of $10.7 billion, or 8.6%, actually beating expectations. “The company\u2019s net sales and operating results were significantly affected by the outbreak of COVID-19,” Walmart said. “Unprecedented demand for products across multiple categories led to strong top-line results. Certain incremental costs negatively affected operating income, including costs associated with enhanced wages and benefits as well as safety and sanitation.”<\/p>\n<p>However, CFO Brett Biggs’ statement on removing guidance underscored how these numbers may not tell the whole story, given the lack of visibility of how the economy, the state of public health and shopping at Walmart will shape up.<\/p>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 4\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<blockquote><p>\u201cThe decision to withdraw guidance reflects significant uncertainty around several key external variables and their potential impact on our business and the global economy, including: the duration and intensity of the COVID- 19 health crisis globally, the length and impact of stay-at-home orders, the scale and duration of economic stimulus, employment trends and consumer confidence,\u201d he noted. \u201cOur business fundamentals are strong, and our financial position is excellent. Customers trust us to deliver on our brand promise, and I\u2019m confident in our ability to perform well in most any environment. While the short-term environment will be challenging, we\u2019re positioned well for long-term success in an increasingly omni world.”<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge of people shopping online. But a number of companies, including Amazon and eBay, have found that handling business at the moment can prove to come with more overhead costs, and that’s before considering what the larger effects of a collapsed economy will have on overall sales longer term, after all the toilet paper and pasta have been acquired. So while it might seem counterintuitive to get rid of Jet.com at a time like this, it’s about cost cutting ultimately because of that bigger picture.<\/p>\n<p>When Walmart made its bold acquisition of Jet.com in 2016, the big ambition was to give the giant retailer a complement to its brick-and-mortar stores to compete better against Amazon and its growing presence as a primary shopping destination. It was also about bringing on its experienced founder and leader Marc Lore — who had already founded and sold an online diaper business to Amazon — to lead both Jet and\u00a0Walmart online.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>\u201cThis is Walmart being even more committed to winning in e-commerce,\u201d said Doug McMillon, president and CEO of Walmart, in a conference call with investors at the time.<\/p>\n<p>But fast forward to today, amid all the strains that COVID-19 is putting on the retail sector and the wider economy, and the\u00a0discontinuation is the final chapter in what ultimately was a problematic endeavour for the company that went through various stages of change. They included, last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/12\/walmart-announces-it-will-fully-integrate-jets-teams-but-jet-will-remain-a-standalone-brand\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">fully integrating Jet’s teams<\/a> into its own;\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/13\/walmarts-jet-com-relaunches-site-with-focus-on-urban-shoppers-same-day-grocery-delivery\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">relaunching<\/a> the service; and also axing various Jet experiments like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/13\/walmart-shuts-down-its-experimental-personal-shopping-service-jet-black\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Jet Black<\/a>, a personal shopping service.<\/p>\n<p>While Walmart does not break out revenues and losses for e-commerce specifically, a report in the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/walmarts-secret-weapon-to-fight-off-amazon-the-supercenter-11576904460\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wall Street Journal<\/a> estimated that losses in e-commerce operations were around $2 billion, actually double what people had been <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fool.com\/investing\/2020\/01\/31\/did-walmart-waste-33-billion-on-jetcom.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">guesstimating just months before<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>In the meantime, Walmart has been working on investing and inventing more Walmart.com perks such as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/30\/walmart-is-piloting-a-pricier-2-hour-express-grocery-delivery-service\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">piloting<\/a> a two-hour deliver service at the end of last month.<\/p>\n<p>The big question now will be whether Walmart can continue to grow its e-commerce business, and reduce its losses, by shifting the focus from an Amazon-style model of fulfilment warehouses to giant stores, which serve a double purpose both to push its brick-and-mortar strategy, and to serve as the fulfilment hubs for the online-facing part of its business.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>So much for Walmart’s big and expensive effort to take on Amazon with a digitally-native brand. Amid the coronavirus crisis and its impact on the retail industry, today the retail giant quietly\u00a0announced in its quarterly report that it would be discontinuing Jet.com, the online-only marketplace that it acquired when it was just over one year elf":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/11160"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=11160"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=11160"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=11160"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1991037,"date":"2020-05-19T12:01:16","date_gmt":"2020-05-19T19:01:16","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1991037"},"modified":"2020-05-19T14:50:28","modified_gmt":"2020-05-19T21:50:28","slug":"spotify-signs-the-joe-rogan-experience-to-an-exclusive-multi-year-deal","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/19\/spotify-signs-the-joe-rogan-experience-to-an-exclusive-multi-year-deal\/","title":{"rendered":"Spotify signs ‘The Joe Rogan Experience’ to an exclusive multi-year deal"},"content":{"rendered":"<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Over the past couple of years, Spotify has demonstrated a long-term commitment to the podcasting format by shelling out money hand over fist. The music streaming service has made a number of high-profile acquisitions, including production company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/02\/06\/spotify-doubles-down-on-podcasts\/\">Gimlet<\/a> and editing tool <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/02\/14\/spotify-gimlet-anchor-340-million\/\">Anchor<\/a>, but today\u2019s news may well be the biggest of all. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The company has signed The Joe Rogan Experience to <a href=\"https:\/\/newsroom.spotify.com\/2020-05-19\/the-joe-rogan-experience-launches-exclusive-partnership-with-spotify\/\">an exclusive multi-year licensing deal<\/a>. The show will hit Spotify September 1, and become exclusive to the platform later in the year. Rogan is arguably the biggest and most influential voice in the medium. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The podcast has dominated Apple\u2019s podcasting charts and YouTube views. Rogan currently has 8.41 million subscribers on YouTube, where his videos regularly rack up more than a million views. A recent interview with Elon Musk has already generated more than 13 million views. As of this writing, the show is currently No. 2 on Apple’s charts and comprises three of the service’s top 10 episodes. “The talk series has long been the most-searched-for podcast on Spotify,” according to the service.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">In an audio message attached to the release, Rogan noted that, \u201cIt will be the exact same show. I will not be an employee of Spotify.\u201d It\u2019s a key point, not just in order to ease the minds of a rabid fan base, but because the left has often been critical of Rogan\u2019s show and message. The program has often featured right-wing voices, including members of the so-called Intellectual Dark Web, Proud Boy founder Gavin McInnes and de-platformed conspiracy trafficker Alex Jones. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Other high-profile guests include Elon Musk, who recently made another appearance on the program, and Senator Bernie Sanders. Sanders\u2019 campaign came under criticism from the DNC establishment after promoting Rogan\u2019s offhanded nomination for president. At the time, the Human Rights Campaign <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/us-news\/2020\/jan\/24\/bernie-sanders-joe-rogan-human-rights-campaign\">said Sanders<\/a> “must reconsider” the endorsement, stating that Rogan has \u201cattacked transgender people, gay men, women, people of color and countless marginalized groups at every opportunity.”<\/span><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">While the show has long been hosted on a variety of audio and video platforms, <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/spotify\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"spotify\">Spotify <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> could well come under fire from similar groups. Rogan has described himself as not belonging to any political party and holding largely libertarian views.<\/p>\n<p>In addition to purchasing existing shows and podcast production companies, Spotify has also been creating its own in-house programs, in a bid to wrest domination of the medium away from long-time leader Apple. This acquisition represents a fairly massive shot across the bow, as diehard fans will soon have no other (legal) option for listening to the show. Details of the deal — including the duration — have not yet been disclosed.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Update:<\/strong> In response to a question about the Rogan show’s history of controversial guests and subject matter, a spokesperson for the company simply responded, “All shows on Spotify are subject to our <a href=\"https:\/\/artists.spotify.com\/faq\/music#what-content-is-prohibited-on-spotify\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/artists.spotify.com\/faq\/music%23what-content-is-prohibited-on-spotify&source=gmail&ust=1590007140966000&usg=AFQjCNHU4n1A2i8TnGV7Sbq5T4cx0Sc3-A\">content policies<\/a>.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Over the past couple of years, Spotify has demonstrated a long-term commitment to the podcasting format by shelling out money hand over fist. The music streaming service has made a number of high-profile acquisitions, including production company Gimlet and editing tool Anchor, but today\u2019s news may well be the biggest of all. The company has v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=2074982"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2074982"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2074982"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":201703114,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?taxonomy=_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy&term=spotify-organization","name":"spotify-organization","slug":"spotify-organization","taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag\/201703114"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?crunchbase_tag=201703114"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[]]}},{"id":1989195,"date":"2020-05-19T08:00:11","date_gmt":"2020-05-19T15:00:11","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989195"},"modified":"2020-05-19T15:46:27","modified_gmt":"2020-05-19T22:46:27","slug":"microsoft-launches-lists-a-new-airtable-like-app-for-microsoft-365","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/19\/microsoft-launches-lists-a-new-airtable-like-app-for-microsoft-365\/","title":{"rendered":"Microsoft launches Lists, a new Airtable-like app for Microsoft 365"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/microsoft\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"microsoft\">Microsoft <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> today launched Lists, a new “smart tracking app” for Microsoft 365 users. That may sound a lot like a to-do list app and, as Microsoft already offers <a href=\"https:\/\/www.microsoft.com\/en-us\/microsoft-365\/microsoft-to-do-list-app\">Microsoft To Do<\/a>, you may wonder why it would bother with Lists. But it seems like Lists goes well beyond a basic to-do app. Indeed, Lists seems more like a competitor to <a href=\"https:\/\/airtable.com\/\">Airtable<\/a>, with the addition of all the usual Microsoft integrations one would expect.<\/p>\n<p>The way Microsoft describes it, Lists is a tool to “track issues, assets, routines, contacts, inventory and more using customizable views and smart rules and alerts to keep everyone in sync.” It features deep integrations into Teams, SharePoint and other Microsoft products and will launch this summer on the web, with mobile apps slated for later this year.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png\"><img class=\"breakout aligncenter size-full wp-image-1989825\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"682\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png 1713w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=1536,1023 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_templates.png?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Based on what Microsoft has shared so far, Lists will feature a bunch of pre-made templates for things like team contacts, event itineraries, business travel approvals and onboarding checklists.<\/p>\n<p>As you can see from that list, it seems like Microsoft has purposely kept the service pretty flexible, so that it can accommodate a lot of use cases. In that respect, it reminds me a bit of services like <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/trello\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"trello\">Trello <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> (and the Lists mobile app bears a striking resemblance to the Trello app).<\/p>\n<p>To enable all of these use cases, Lists include different ways to visualize your lists. For now, there are three views: grid, gallery and calendar. The standard view is “grid,” which may remind you a bit of <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/airtable\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"airtable\">Airtable, <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> if you have ever used that. <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/calendar\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"calendar\">Calendar <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> view explains itself, while the gallery view is ideal for anything that’s more visual. And because Lists seems to be all about flexibility, you can also create custom views.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png\"><img class=\"breakout aligncenter size-full wp-image-1990493\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"662\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png 1260w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png?resize=150,97 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png?resize=300,194 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png?resize=768,497 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png?resize=680,440 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Annotation-2020-05-18-181625.png?resize=50,32 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n<p>Unlike Airtable, though, Lists doesn’t seem to feature a Kanban view or the ability to enter data through custom forms.<\/p>\n<p>Another major feature of Lists is its system for creating rules. “Once you decide on the outcome, click through if\/then steps to evolve your rules,” writes Microsoft in today’s announcement. “Choose people, status, and value changes to send notifications or programmatically update values elsewhere in the list. Finally, use rules to set reminders to keep you and your team informed.”<\/p>\n<p>Because all things Microsoft currently lead to Teams sooner or later, the company is obviously stressing that Lists are obviously integrated with Teams, too, similar to other apps inside the company’s communications platform.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png\"><img class=\"breakout aligncenter size-full wp-image-1989828\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"678\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png 1815w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=150,99 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=300,199 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=768,509 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=680,450 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=1536,1017 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/lists_gallery.png?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/microsoft-build-2020\/\"><img src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/msft-build-2020-banner.jpg\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Microsoft today launched Lists, a new “smart tracking app” for Microsoft 365 users. and Instagram roll out Shops, turning business profiles into storefronts"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Starting today, you’ll be able to browse and buy products directly from a business’ <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/facebook\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"facebook\">Facebook <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Page or Instagram profile.<\/p>\n<p>Both Facebook and <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/instagram\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"instagram\">Instagram <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> already supported a degree of e-commerce \u2014 for example, Facebook has its <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/06\/06\/facebook-marketplace-ads\/\">Marketplace<\/a> and will likely make a bigger push through <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/21\/shopify-libra\/\">its Libra cryptocurrency initiative<\/a>, while <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/03\/19\/instagram-checkout\/\">Instagram allows users to buy products<\/a> featured in posts and ads. But the company’s new tools go further, enabling businesses to create a full-fledged Facebook Shop.<\/p>\n<p>After all, the pandemic has probably made consumers even more likely to treat Facebook and Instagram profiles as the go-to source of information on local restaurants and stores \u2014 if your favorite store has changed their hours, or switched to online delivery\/curbside pickup, they\u2019ve almost certainly posted about it on Facebook or Instagram. So why not allow visitors to make purchases without having to leave the Facebook and Instagram apps?<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>It\u2019s also worth remembering that the pandemic\u2019s economic fallout is already hurting and killing off many small businesses \u2014 businesses that post and advertise on Facebook. So the company has a stake in helping those businesses survive <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/17\/facebook-small-business-grants\/\">in any way it can.<\/a><\/p>\n<p>In a Facebook Live session today, CEO Mark Zuckerberg described this as a way to help businesses suffering in the wake of COVID-19, though he acknowledged it will not “undo all the economic damage.”<\/p>\n<p>He also suggested that this will remain useful after the pandemic: “I do think we\u2019re going to continue living more of our lives online and doing more business online.”<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1990937\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1990937\" class=\"size-large wp-image-1990937\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"Instagram Shops\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Instagram-Shops_color.jpeg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1990937\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Facebook<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, Instagram’s vice president of product Vishal Shah told me this is a big, global test of the feature, with nearly 1 million businesses already signed up.<\/p>\n<p>Those businesses will be able to create a Facebook Shop for free \u2014 they just upload their catalog, choose the products they want to feature, then customize it with a cover image and accent colors. Visitors can then browse, save and order products.<\/p>\n<p>Facebook’s vice president of ads Dan Levy said that while the company will charge “small fees” on each purchase, the real monetization will come from driving more advertising. (Shops can also be featured in ads and stories.)<\/p>\n<p>Levy described this as a “build and render anywhere” solution, with Shah adding that “the shop itself will be\u00a0very consistent, whether it\u2019s on Facebook or Instagram.” What will differ is how consumers discover the shops, whether it’s via the Facebook Marketplace or a product tagged in a photo on Instagram.<\/p>\n<p>The company also plans to launch this summer another experience called Instagram Shop, allowing users to browse products directly from Instagram Explore and eventually to jump into a shopping experience from the app’s main navigation tab. There will also be ways for merchants to feature and link in their live videos products from their Facebook Stores, and for consumers to connect loyalty programs to their Facebook accounts.<\/p>\n<p>As part of this announcement, Facebook said it’s partnering with\u00a0Shopify, BigCommerce, Woo, Channel\u00a0Advisor, CedCommerce, Cafe24, Tienda Nube and Feedonomics.<\/p>\n<p>Merchants will be able to use these third-party platforms to manage their Facebook Shops, as well as the ads tied to those Shops. For example, Shopify said, “Facebook Shops allows Shopify merchants to get control over customization and merchandising for their storefronts inside Facebook and Instagram, while managing their products, inventory, orders, and fulfillment directly from within Shopify.”<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"3W3zd2zUyt\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/17\/facebook-small-business-grants\/\">Facebook announces $100M grant program for small businesses<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"“Facebook announces $100M grant program for small businesses” — TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/17\/facebook-small-business-grants\/embed\/#?secret=3W3zd2zUyt\" data-secret=\"3W3zd2zUyt\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Starting today, you’ll be able to browse and buy products directly from a business’ Facebook Page or Instagram profile. these 6 top VCs are investing in cannabis"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">The cannabis market<\/span> was in the midst of a correction when the COVID-19 crisis hit and could emerge stronger than ever. <\/span><\/p>\n<p>After a breakthrough period of growth, cannabis startups entered 2020 with depressed values and an uncertain future. Now, with millions sheltering in place, many companies are seeing unprecedented demand and growth opportunities as many states classified the industry as an essential business.<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch surveyed top investors focused on the cannabis market to gather their thoughts on current trends and opportunities. The results paint a stunning picture of an industry on the verge of breaking away from a market correction. Our six respondents described numerous opportunities for startups and investors, but cautioned that this atmosphere will not last long.<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li>Sean Stiefel, CEO, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.navycapital.com\/\">Navy Capital<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Matt Hawkins, Founder\/Managing Partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/entourageeffectcapital.com\/\">Entourage Effect Capital<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Karan Wadhera, Managing Partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.casaverdecapital.com\/\">Casa Verde Capital LLC<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Larry Schnurmacher, Managing Partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.phytopartners.com\/\">Phyto Partners<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Mitch Baruchowitz, Managing Partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.meridacap.com\/\">Merida Capital Partners<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Morgan Paxhia, Managing Director, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.poseidonassetmanagement.com\/\">Poseidon Investment Management<\/a><\/li>\n<li>Emily Paxhia, Managind Director, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.poseidonassetmanagement.com\/\">Poseidon Investment Management<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h2>Three key takeaways<\/h2>\n<p><strong>Cannabis is an essential business<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Per the investors in our survey, most see the the pandemic as a turning point for cannabis thanks to increased demand and the industry’s designation as an essential business. <\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Sean Stiefel, CEO of Navy Capital, notes that states will look to cannabis to help resolve budget deficits and said his firm is especially excited for legalization in <\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>“Cannabis went from illegal to essential in about two weeks flat,” said Matt Hawkins of Entourage Effect Capital. “Cannabis is now listed right alongside hospitals, doctors, grocery stores, gas stations and fire departments as an essential service.”<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The cannabis market was in the midst of a correction when the COVID-19 crisis hit and could emerge stronger than ever. runch.com\/?p=1990636"},"modified":"2020-05-19T06:50:32","modified_gmt":"2020-05-19T13:50:32","slug":"popping-the-hood-on-vrooms-ipo-filing","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/19\/popping-the-hood-on-vrooms-ipo-filing\/","title":{"rendered":"Popping the hood on Vroom’s IPO filing"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Hello and welcome<\/span> back to our regular morning look at private companies, public markets and the gray space in between.<\/p>\n<p>Yesterday afternoon, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.vroom.com\/\">Vroom<\/a>, an online car buying service, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/1580864\/000119312520145219\/d801274ds1.htm\">filed to go public<\/a>. Based on its SEC filing, Vroom is a highly-successful private company in fundraising terms that has attracted <a href=\"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/organization\/vroom-com#section-funding-rounds\">over $700 million<\/a> during its life as a startup. T. Rowe Price, AutoNation, Durable Capital Partners, General Catalyst and other investors fueled the firm during its youth according to Crunchbase data.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/vroom-com\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"vroom-com\">Vroom <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> most recently <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/12\/06\/online-used-car-startup-vroom-raises-254m-to-scale-product-and-engineering-hub\/\">raised $254 million in December 2019<\/a>, a Series H round that <a href=\"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/funding_round\/vroom-com-series-h--6a7cd824#section-lead-investors\">valued the company<\/a> at around $1.5 billion. From its mid-2013 Series A to today, Vroom has tried to accelerate from the startup world to the grown-up domain of the public markets. How did it do?<\/p>\n<p>Finding out is our goal this morning. We’re also curious why the firm would pursue an IPO today; public offerings tend to shun volatile, uncertain periods. So let’s dig into the numbers and do a bit of a unicorn check-up.<\/p>\n<p>What does a private, car-focused e-commerce company worth $1.5 billion look like under the hood?<\/p>\n<h2>Un-profits<\/h2>\n<p>TechCrunch <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/12\/the-future-of-car-ownership-building-an-online-dealership\/\">dug into Vroom’s market last year<\/a>, writing that the company “looks a lot like Carvana and Shift,” and noting that in 2018 the company had “laid off 25-50% of its staff as it exited several markets.” <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/vroom-com\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"vroom-com\">Vroom <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> was therefore a bit early to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/15\/unicorn-layoffs-keep-piling-up-as-the-economy-gets-worse\/\">the waves of unicorn layoffs<\/a> that we’ve seen in 2020.<\/p>\n<p>I raise the layoffs as they imply that the company might be in reasonable financial shape; what did the cuts buy the company in terms of profitability?<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>What does a private, car-focused e-commerce company worth $1.5 billion look stadiums closed, TV networks turn to live esports broadcasts"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">The COVID-19 pandemic<\/span> has wiped out the spring seasons for professional sports and associated revenue for TV networks, but esports is filling part of that void.<\/p>\n<p>Gaming companies behind titles licensed by each major league are the winners in this unexpected shift. <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/electronicarts\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"electronicarts\">Electronic Arts <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> (EA) is first among them with FIFA, Madden NFL, NBA Live and NHL in its EA Sports portfolio and <a href=\"https:\/\/s22.q4cdn.com\/894350492\/files\/doc_financials\/2020\/q4\/FY20-Q4-Earnings-Release-(1).pdf\">more than 100 esports events<\/a> planned for 2020. The way EA, networks and sports leagues are responding to production challenges in this crisis will reshape the esports market going forward.<\/p>\n<p>Millions of people sheltering in place has created a breakout opportunity for esports broadcasting:<\/p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A large portion of the internet-using population is at home 24\/7, with screens as their main entertainment outlet.<\/li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Sports fans have few competitive live events to watch.<\/li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Broadcasters like ESPN, CBS, and Sky lost their most valuable content for attracting live viewers and need alternative content.<\/li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Star athletes and non-sports celebrities are stuck at home with wide-open schedules.<\/li>\n<\/ol>\n<p>In late March, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sportspromedia.com\/news\/nfl-fox-tv-rights-madden-esports-tournament-fs1\">900,000 viewers tuned into Fox Sports<\/a> for Nascar\u2019s iRacing series, with <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sportsmediawatch.com\/2020\/04\/iracing-ratings-nascar-indycar-nba-2k-players-basketball-hof\/\">1.1 million watching in early April<\/a>; the network has also broadcast Madden NFL tournaments with <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/nfl\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"nfl\">NFL <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> commentators and athletes. ESPN is televising <a href=\"https:\/\/www.espn.com\/esports\/story\/_\/id\/28993742\/overheard-nba-2k20-player-tournament\">NBA players facing off against each other in NBA 2K<\/a> (by Take-Two Interactive) and pro drivers (and other pro athletes like Manchester City striker Sergio Aguero) are racing each other in Codemasters\u2019 F1 2019 game. ESPN has broadcast competitive play of non-sports games with League of Legends (by Riot Games) and Apex Legends (by EA) tournaments.<\/p>\n<p>To be clear, ratings for these events have varied widely, but networks and game companies are rethinking how esports is broadcast, which will advance its pop culture appeal.<\/p>\n<h2>Games adapting pro sports are best bridge to non-gamers<\/h2>\n<p>Esports is a massively popular activity with its own large piece of turf in pop culture, but it hasn’t secured a central role. Research firm <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/newzoo\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"newzoo\">Newzoo <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> pegs the global audience of \u201cesports enthusiasts\u201d at 223 million. But unlike soccer and basketball, esports is siloed because it caters to viewers who are generally avid gamers. The action is extremely fast, so commentary by a streamer rarely helps outsiders understand what is going on enough to become engaged.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Two years from now, people will look back at 2020’s COVID-19 lockdown as a pivot point in esports\u2019 countries need ‘startup acts’ more than ever to support innovation"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Adedana Ashebir<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/villagecapital\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tAdedana Ashebir is regional manager for Africa for <a href=\"https:\/\/vilcap.com\/\">Village Capital<\/a>, which has supported more than 100 entrepreneurs and 15 entrepreneur support organizations in Sub-Saharan Africa since 2012.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">As the fallout<\/span> from COVID-19 continues to grip Africa\u2019s major economies, the tech ventures in those countries need state support.<\/p>\n<p>National legislation that creates clear frameworks and operational support for startups are one of the best ways to help Africa\u2019s digital companies survive and thrive through the coronavirus crisis \u2014 and improve their environment over the long term.<\/p>\n<p>Africa has dozens of thriving startup ecosystems that are <a href=\"https:\/\/qz.com\/africa\/1820515\/coronavirus-nigerian-startups-piggyvest-irokotv-try-remote-work\/\">persevering<\/a> through this crisis, but now more than ever, they need a boost. The gains made by founders thus far are in danger due to the ongoing economic slowdown. The <a href=\"https:\/\/openknowledge.worldbank.org\/bitstream\/handle\/10986\/33541\/9781464815683.pdf?sequence=10&isAllowed=y\">World Bank estimates<\/a> that economic growth in sub-Saharan Africa alone will decline from 2.4% last year to -2.1 to -5.1% this year. If correct, the region will experience its first recession in a quarter of a century.<\/p>\n<p>Now is the time for something that was already long-overdue in many African countries: political leaders should support startups through national startup acts.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1990376\" style=\"width: 5045px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1990376\" class=\"breakout wp-image-1990376 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"5035\" height=\"3121\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg 5035w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=150,93 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=300,186 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=768,476 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=680,422 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=1536,952 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=2048,1269 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/Adedana-Ashebir-headshot-landscape-Village-Capital.jpg?resize=50,31 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 5035px) 100vw, 5035px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1990376\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Village Capital’s Adedana Ashebir, Image Credits: Village Capital<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Last December, Senegal became the second African nation to enact a national Startup Act, following Tunisia\u2019s <a href=\"https:\/\/qz.com\/africa\/1252113\/tunisia-startup-act-to-boost-african-tech-ecosystem-and-innovation\/\">landmark bill<\/a> that passed in April 2018. Other countries may follow soon: startup legislation was being discussed in <a href=\"https:\/\/disrupt-africa.com\/2019\/07\/10-more-african-countries-are-working-towards-local-startup-acts\/\">Ghana<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/afrikanheroes.com\/2019\/04\/24\/mali-is-set-to-have-a-startup-act\/\">Mali<\/a> before the novel coronavirus monopolized headlines.<\/p>\n<p>The rest of the continent can learn a lot from Tunisia, which passed its Startup Act in 2018 after receiving input from entrepreneurs and economists. In addition to clarifying rules surrounding angel, seed and venture capital funding, the act bestows benefits on companies designated as startups. This includes alleviating their tax and social security contribution burdens, providing access to forex bank accounts and offering subsidized salaries for founders. More than 50 startups have taken advantage of the \u201cstartup\u201d label. A number of Tunisian entrepreneurs have told me that thanks to the new legislation, they are able reinvest savings from these incentives back into their businesses.<div views on the future of work, coffee shops and neighborhoods in a post-pandemic world"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">The novel coronavirus<\/span> pandemic has disordered traditional notions of work, travel, socializing and the way we collaborate with colleagues.<\/p>\n<p>It seems obvious that the future of work must evolve, given what we’re experiencing, but what will that future look like? Which changes are here to stay and which ones will revert the moment offices reopen?<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/techcrunch\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"techcrunch\">TechCrunch <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> has been a WFH employer for essentially its entire existence. Our staff is distributed across major startup hubs like SF and NYC, but we also have writers in smaller cities around the world, so we compiled reflections and thoughts from three of them about how remote work has changed our lifestyles and what we predict to see in the next few years, post-COVID 19.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/person\/devin-coldewey\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"person\" data-entity=\"devin-coldewey\">Devin Coldewey <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> talks about what\u2019s going to change with coffee shops and co-working spaces, Alex Wilhelm discusses the future of the home office setup and Danny Crichton talks about the revitalization of urban and semi-urban neighborhoods.<\/p>\n<h2>Devin Coldewey on coffee shops and more flexible work arrangements<\/h2>\n<p>I’ve worked from home for over a decade and part of what makes it so lovely is the ability to do my work from a nearby cafe, or even a restaurant or bar. I’m lucky in that my part of the city is famously packed with excellent coffee shops, but in the time I’ve lived here I’ve seen them grow increasingly packed with \u2014 well, people like me. Some days they seem more like co-working spaces than cafes \u2014 and this is something business owners and neighborhoods are going to need to acknowledge one way or the other.<\/p>\n<p>Most urban and suburban American communities were formed around the convention of commuting, which means fewer work-related resources where people live. Instead, we have all the restaurants, bodegas, thrift stores and all the other things that cater to people who aren’t working.<div social Zoom competitor Messenger Rooms goes live globally"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/zoom-video-communications\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"zoom-video-communications\">Zoom <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> was never meant to be a social network, but the enterprise video chat app has become essential software for those looking to stay in touch with friends and family during the pandemic.<\/p>\n<p>Today, <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/facebook\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"facebook\">Facebook <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> looks to steal back the service’s social video chat growth as it globally launches Messenger Rooms, its new group video chat service, supporting video calls with up to 50 participants with no time limits on call length. The feature capitalizes on video chat’s massive spike in usage across services and hooks it up to the growth tactics Facebook used to push <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/facebook\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"facebook\">Facebook <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> and Instagram Live into everyone’s feeds.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/messenger\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"messenger\">Messenger <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Rooms is a drop-in video chat, so when a friend using the feature creates a room, Facebook will alert users via a new section in the news feed or push a notification to certain friends. As Facebook detailed when it announced the feature, soon users will also be able to join and initiate calls from inside <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/instagram\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"instagram\">Instagram <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> DMs, WhatsApp and on Portal, making this a company-wide social effort for the company.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>For now users can kick off a call from Messenger or the Facebook app and send out invites to users, even ones that don\u2019t have a Facebook account.<\/p>\n<p>During the latest earnings call, Facebook CEO <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/person\/mark-zuckerberg\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"person\" data-entity=\"mark-zuckerberg\">Mark Zuckerberg <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> said time on group video chats had increased 1,000% in recent weeks. Given the feature’s social grounding and lack of screen sharing, the app isn’t likely to scale heavily into enterprise use cases and infringe on Zoom’s core business. With Messenger Rooms, Facebook is looking to create a scalable, free alternative and steal back some of the conversation from platforms like Zoom and TikTok, which have been awfully buzzy during recent months.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"pRw3YAEMfI\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/24\/faceboo-launches-drop-in-video-chat-rooms-to-rival-houseparty\/\">Facebook launches drop-in video chat Rooms to rival Houseparty<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"“Facebook launches drop-in video chat Rooms to rival Houseparty” — TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/24\/faceboo-launches-drop-in-video-chat-rooms-to-rival-houseparty\/embed\/#?secret=pRw3YAEMfI\" data-secret=\"pRw3YAEMfI\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p> <\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Zoom was never meant to be a social network, but the enterprise video chat app has become essential software for those looking to stay in touch with friends and family during the pandemic.
